contentList.content: Massive and brutal. When you looked inside, you saw countless mountains of blades gleaming with unnatural light. Must be supplies for the Great Magical War?
It belonged to an insidious cannibal warlock who lured tired winter travellers into his warm cave. The blade glinted furiously with sparks and seemed to sizzle faintly.
When a foe dies from your[1], all non-allied creatures within [2] take [3].

Sealed for centuries, but once discovered by unlucky treasure seekers, this terrifying artefact will bring death and strife to every land it enters. To wield the power of this dagger is to become almost equal to Bhaal.
Scoring a Critical Hit with a spell or cantrip, you gain [1] charge of Fierce Desire.

You gain +[1] to a spell Attack Rolls for each charge of Fierce Desire. After accumulating [2] charges, you absorb them and gain [3] charge of Fierce Reaping.

Dispels only after a Long Rest.

You gain Advantage on a spell Attack Rolls. +[1] to Spell Save DC for each charge of this effect.

Dispels with a [2]% chance after scoring a Critical Hits with a spell or cantrip.

According to the beliefs, far away in the mountains was a temple for the supernatural practice of releasing one's soul into vessels. One day, the members of this sect made a great and final sacrifice - they transferred their souls into a horrific dagger. That dagger has since been lost under a thick layer of time's dust. But whoever finds it will have the strength of a thousand monks' souls.
Spending <LSTag Type="ActionResource" Tooltip="KiPoint">Ki</LSTag> in combat, you <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="WEAPON3">saturate youself with souls</LSTag> until the start of your turn.
Enchanted by the city's criminal magician, this dagger has repeatedly rescued unlucky assassins who failed to finish the job. Despite its antiquity, it still retains much of its charms.
When you miss a foe with a spell or a weapon attack, you inflict an endless Enchanted Poison.

This creature takes [3] each turn and has a [1]~[2] penalty to Saving Throws.

Creature can dispel this effect at the end of each turn if it succeeds a Constitution Saving Throw([4]).
This strange artefact, created by an ancient master, can apparently tear the very fabric of the Weave and infuse its bearer with magic.
When you roll a [1] or lower on a damage die for a spell or cantrip, you reroll the die three times and choose the best result each time. Do this for each spell damage die.
Demonic in nature, this dagger still encapsulates the power of its former owner, slain in a senseless war.

Each time you deal[1] to a creature with a spell or a cantrip in combat, regain [2]. Triggers once per attack.

Effectiveness increases every [3] levels.

The tattered dagger, with its particles of tarnish, gleams aloofly, but with the kind of hopefulness that usually comes from a piece of bread for a poor man. The healing properties of this artefact will surely benefit any magician engaged in mortal struggles.

Healing yourself or an ally with a spell or a cantrip in combat creates a blast of healing cloud that regains [2] to all creatures within a [1] radius.

Triggers no more than once per turn.
The space around the artefact fluctuates noticeably, as if constantly blown by a piercing wind. As you grip the hilt tightly, you feel the dagger begin to vibrate faintly.
Dealing[1] to a non-large creature in combat with any means, you push it back for [2].

Legend has it that the king used to look round his domain in the guise of a raven, a spell granted to him by an enchanted dagger. One day, assassins caught him in his bedroom and wounded him. The king immediately grabbed the dagger and flew out an open window, but one of the assassins called down a thunderstorm and killed the raven with a crack of thunder. The artefact absorbed the power of the lightning, feeding off the great king's death throes.

Using Jump or Fly in combat, you gain [1] Lightning Charges. If you are already have Lightning Charges, gain only [2].

Triggers no more than once per turn.

Belonged to a petty coachman who used to cruelly murder rich passengers after getting them drunk. His perversions went so far that he even had his favourite murder weapon enchanted by a warlock hermit.

Attacking a Charmed or Frightened target, you regain Action Point, Bonus Action Point and take [1], even if you miss.

Triggers no more than once per turn.

This dagger was not simple, but of great power. Formerly in the possession of a winter wizard, it allowed to draw essence from foes with the help of magical cold and even to dry people to a crust of ice. Unfortunately, only that wizard possessed all the secrets of this artefact.
Dealing damage to a creature with a spell or a cantrip while you standing on a frozen surface, grants you [2]. There is also a [1]% chance that a foe will be instantly freeze-dried to death.

The same dagger with which the famous but drunken Guérin had stabbed the heir to the crown in the belly and then paid for it with his own head. The dagger is worn, but still bears the mark of the incredible adventures of the battle mage who ended his journey so ignominiously.

Entering Rage, regain all your Level [1] Spell Slots and Channel Oath Charges.

Triggers no more than once per combat.

The aristocrat who wielded this noble dagger seemed an uneasy elf. He could shoot an apple from three hundred metres with a bow: in a strong wind, while simultaneously writing his autobiography and incessantly saying how easy it is for him. He believed himself to be immortal, until, at last, he accidentally dropped his dagger during a fight with the gnolls - and there perished to the amusement of his peers.

The mountains have always called out to Zadrotic. This disciple of the Druids had always been a pariah among his own, never accepting order. Finding himself in the barren mountains, in ten years he turned this no-man's land into a thriving garden for the animals of all kinds that worshipped him. In the midst of a hostile environment, he learnt to harness the forces of nature to protect his new kingdom, especially becoming enamoured of the lightning power.
Scoring a Critical Hit with a weapon attack, also deal [1].
Summon a [1] electrified surface at the target location for [2] turns.

Once upon a time, there was a peasant. Then the plague came to his land and took his wife. So the man went to the warlock to ask how he could save his children, but suddenly the warlock was attacked by soldiers! Thus the man had to grab the first dagger lying around and save the conjurer. The witch doctor rewarded the man, gave him the necessary advice and let him go away. But the king's gallows was waiting for the man. And the plague was waiting for the children.

Inflicting Fear on a foe, you gain [1] charges of Fear Essences.

Triggers no more than once per Short Rest.
Fear Essences dispels if there are more than [1] of them. Dispels after a Long Rest.
When you miss a foe, you spend one charge of Fear Essences and apply Fear for [2] turns, if a foe fails a Wisdom Saving Throw([1]).
The sinister dagger glints with an unnatural pale green glow and wants to tell a lot more than its former owner would allow. The artefact whispers only one word: DISPLEASED.
When you deal[1] to a foe, you gain Myrkul's Outrage with a [2]% chance.
Your next spell, weapon or unarmed attack is guaranteed to score a Critical Hit.

According to stories, this dagger came to us from a faraway land, the kind of land that they say "gives you the chills". And whether it was wielded by a very wise monk or a cunning magician, one thing is certain - this dagger has a truly inhuman magic.

Killing a foe, you gain Liquid Extraction for [1] turns, the duration of which can be accumulated for each kill.

Triggers no more than once per combat.

Your Ray of Frost and Chill of the Mountain also deal [1]. By losing this effect, you take [2].

Does not dispels after a Long Rest.

In this mysterious dagger is locked a certain Kraepon. Who he is and when he was imprisoned there, no one will ever know. Kraepon usually makes various magical deals with the owners of the dagger out of boredom, trying to fool them as much as possible.
The creature inside the dagger convinces you to make a deal. At the start of each combat, you are subject to Painful Deal.

Creatures you summon within [1] radius get Ethereal Control.

Dispels at the end of combat.
This creature gains +[2]~[3] to Attack Rolls. When a creature loses this effect for any reason, it takes [1].

It cannot be said that the main occupation of the former owner of this dagger was singing. He used singing to distract the crowd while his associates picked the pockets of rich ladies. Of course, afterwards, one had to bow out gallantly - or flee very quickly.

When you damage a Charmed creature, regain all Bonus Action Points.

Triggers no more than once per turn.
Astonishingly, this ancient dagger still hasn't shattered - an unknown powerful magic holds it together. The artefact can definitely save both itself and its owner from imminent demise.

If you damage a foe with this dagger and have no more than [1]% HP, gain Gluing Wounds for [2] turns.

Triggers no more than once per turn.
At the end of each turn, you regain [1]. The amount of healing depends on your level and Spell Casting Modifier. Dispels when taking damage.

The queen had not yet given birth to a child, but a dagger had already been raised over her to break the royal line. The assassin was a court magician who had been convinced by travelling opportunists that the queen was carrying a monster that would reduce the entire kingdom to ashes and tears. Fortunately, the scoundrel was stabbed to death by the guards, and his soul was imprisoned in this dagger and hung on the wall of the king's bedchamber.
Entering stealth, burn one Level [2] Spell Slot and gain Arcane Synergy. If Spell Slot is not spent, nothing happens.

Your melee weapon attack deals an additional [3]. Effectiveness increases from your Spell Casting Modifier.

Dispels when you exit stealth.

The jester was said to be a madman, and even a practitioner of the dark arts! He was a regular in the dirtiest institutions, and told jokes that would make even grown men's hair stand on end. He was at the royal courts, where the ladies fainted from the sharpness of his verbal turns. Yet he ended very badly, but that is another anecdote.
At the start of combat, you gain <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="WEAPON22">Court Joke</LSTag>.

Your Attack Rolls with spells have an Advantage, but Attack Rolls with or without weapon have Disadvantage. Turns into Tavern Joke at the end of the turn.

Dispels at the end of combat.

Your Attack Rolls with or without weapon have Advantage, but Attack Rolls with spells have Disadvantage. Turns into Court Joke at the end of the turn.

Dispels at the end of combat.

Enchanted in the royal libraries, this dagger was one of the ordinary experiments of court magicians trying to find a way to turn metal into gold. They successfully lost the blade, and it was a servant who stumbled upon it. With his heel.

When you deal damage with this dagger to a creature, you become Invisible for [1] turns.

Triggers no more than once per combat.

The blade of this dagger reflects all human vices when a sinless one is looking at it. But when a sinner looks at the blade, all he sees in the reflection is himself on the throne. And only a sinner can benefit from this artefact.
By applying any condition to a foe in combat, there is a [1]% chance you gain [2] charge of Sin Magic.

For each charge of this effect, you gain +[1] to Intelligence, Wisdom and Charisma, but losing [1] to Constitution.

After accumulating [2] charges, you absorb them and regain all Spell Slots and Warlock Spell Slots.
When dealing damage to a foe in combat, you have a [1]% chance to apply Curse of Regret for [2] turns.

Long has it had a will of its own, long has it been hungry for new meal. It can tell the future, it can look deep into the past, it can even change the very fabric of existence. But it will do none of these things until its master brings it some food.
As long as you carry this dagger, it will demand for souls. You start each new day with Exhausted Hilt and must fill it with cursed souls.

When you kill a cursed foe, the dagger of Fate infuses its hilt with a fresh soul, granting its wielder saturation bonuses.

Any curse will do.
Dagger drains your fate, causing you to roll [1] less on all dice.
Dagger still needs cursed souls. You roll [1] less on all dice.
Hilt feeds on cursed souls, and does not have any effect on you.
Dagger begins to change your fate, causing you to roll [1] more on all dice.
Dagger is nourished and performs wonders on you. You roll [1] more on all dice.

Belonged to the long-dead Langorath, a noble servant of Ketharon. The last time this weapon was used in battle, it drew fountains of blood on the battlefield. That was 2600 years ago, but since then the flail has remained in perfect condition and is ready for glorious battles.

You deal an extra [1] with your melee weapon attacks.

Effectiveness increases from your Charisma Modifier.

A thin red trickle runs down the rusty, dead-pale metal of the chains, spilling from somewhere in the handle. The flail, despite its antiquity, is extremely reliable and arouses great fear at the sight of it.

A foe that takes damage from this flail must succeed a Wisdom Saving Throw([1]) or recieve Fear for [2] turns.

Can be equipped offhand.

Once upon a time, long ago, there was a hidden temple in the desert. But it was not the shrine of a god, but of a tree. The defenseless tree was a powerful source of magic, for which the temple's inhabitants protected it and fed on the tree's gifts. When the barbarians found the temple, they destroyed the tree, but one elf managed to escape with a piece of bark - from which he made the core for this flail.
Core from the Tree of Worship

Using Channel Divinity or Channel Oath in combat, you gain Blessing of the Tree for [1] turns.

Triggers no more than once per combat.
You gain <LSTag Tooltip="Advantage">Advantage</LSTag> on <LSTag Tooltip="AttackRoll">Attack Rolls</LSTag>.

In the olden days, there lived an adventurer, a fortunate hunter of unusual game. On one of his stunning hunts, he managed to catch a gnoll and a fey at the same time. However, the latter offered a bargain for her freedom - and turned the gnoll into the perfect weapon of war, a master flail.

Attacking with this weapon will restore an Action Point with a [1]% chance.

Can be equipped offhand.

An unusual flail charged with a charm of good. The flail was last seen in the hands of the gobliness Glaxie, who led her companions in great conquests. But how did she get her hands on such an artefact?

By healing yourself or an ally with a spell, target gains Clarity of Mind for the rest of the combat.

Triggers no more than once per turn.

This creature thinks more clearly and directs its attacks better. It gains +[1]~[2] to Attack Rolls.

Dispels at the end of combat.

This flail was the weapon of mass murder for an entire village, where an evil warlock and his minions bullied old men and children while the men were at war. The sinister weapon, however, has since been lost - and perhaps it is for the best.
When you use a spell or a cantrip on a foe, you may apply Tormenting Curse for [1] turn.

This creature takes [1]~[2] more damage from all sources.

Duration of the effect can be stacked.

A fisherman who happened to see a glint of metal in the depths of the coastal sea became rich in an instant. The piece of ore was a rare magical metal from which the coastal people created an impressive piece of weaponry for their best warrior. For thousands of years it was passed from one warrior to another, until finally the last member of the dynasty was traitorously stabbed in the back during a major battle.

When you deal damage to a foe with this flail, heal yourself and your allies for [1].

Triggers no more than once per turn.

Great and mighty, the Shadow Clan had ruled an entire continent in the old days, secretly of course. Nothing escaped its eyes, and its members were immortal as they drew power from their cruel artefacts that gave them the might of the shadow itself. The clan became so powerful that it fell under the onslaught of internal intrigue.
When your HP is less than [1]%, you gain Shadow Gifts for the rest of combat.

You restore one Warlock Spell Slot at the start of each turn.

Dispels at the end of combat.

The sickle glows fiercely in shades of red, as if inadvertently exposing the insatiable magic imprisoned within it. The handle is made of the skin of an unknown creature, and the blade itself can be used to cut bear skin into perfect strips.
Taking damage from this sickle, creature must succeed a Constitution Saving Throw([1]) or suffer Deep Bleeding for [2] turns.

This creature takes [1] each turn.

If bleeding duration reaches [2] turns or more, creature takes [3] and bleeding ends. The magic of deep bleeding allows this effect to be applied even to creatures that are immune to bleeding.

This exquisite weapon belonged to an elven priestess of the Whisperwind clan. This enchanted sickle had passed many trials of endurance with her, but on the last one it failed - the gnolls had trapped and exhausted the poor elf in pursuit of this tempting artefact.
When you miss with this sickle, you gain Magic Swirls for [1] turns.

When you hit a creature with this sickle, regain all your Level [2] Spell Slots.

Triggers no more than once per Short Rest.

The mark of Selûne on the hilt firmly identifies who the sickle once belonged to. Its powers have not waned over the years under the moonlight and the mysterious stars, but have only grown stronger. It seems that the goddess herself favours the owner of this artefact and grants a blessing in any endeavour.

When you heal a creature with a spell, also regain them [1].

Amount of healing depends on your Spellcasting Ability Modifier.

This hastily crafted killing tool made from someone's huge bones is nonetheless a serious threat to any opponent of the wielder. The blade is not so sharp, but a subtle ancient magic shreds soft objects right in the path of the swing of this weapon. Useful for hunting large beasts.
Taking damage from this sickle, creature must succeed a Dexterity Saving Throw([1]) or suffer Blight for [2] turn.
+[1] to a weapon Attack Rolls against beasts.

One day, the king's counsellor decided to marry his daughter to the crown prince. To achieve this, he contacted a cunning warlock with whom he made a dark bargain - the counsellor must slay 10,000 innocents with a particular sickle, then the king would immediately approve the engagement. Thus began Attanick's great quest for souls, which ended only 500 years later, when his daughter was long dead, still a mere lowborn.
When you deal damage with this sickle, deal [1], but receive [2] charge of Part of the Bargain.

You lose [1] of your HP for each charge of this effect.

Dispels at the end of combat.
-[1] to damage. When dealing damage to a foe with a targeted spell, you gain [2] charge of Vitality Surge.

Your HP is increased by [1] for each charge of this effect.

Dispels at the end of combat.

The druids guarded their grove night and day. They were assisted in doing so by this artefact, said to have been given to the grove by Sylvanus Himself. The ability of this magic sickle to connect with nature amazed the adepts, and many were envious, greedy, and eager to possess this power. The traitor eventually chopped down the entire Whispering Grove with the same sickle.
At the start of each turn, the forces of nature are awaking, Entangling all foes within a [2] radius, if they fail a Dexterity Saving Throw([3]).

Zirrisk was a dangerous predator 20,000 years ago, during the time of Haeshkarr's campaign against the elven kingdoms. Zirrisk was very fond of orc meat, and regularly raided horde wagons, taking a couple of thousand orcs with him for feeding. Haeshkarr soon learnt of this and personally went on the hunt. He was unable to kill this super-predator, but he did manage to tear out its fangs, which discouraged any desire to devour any more orcs.
Taking damage from this sickle, creature must succeed a Constitution Saving Throw([1]) or be inflicted with Immobilising Venom for [2] turns.
This creature cannot regain Hit Points or move.
Upon becoming the target of your levelled spell, a foe must succeed a Wisdom Saving Throw([1]) or suffer a [2] charge of Curse of Weakness.

This creature loses [1] Constitution for each charge of this effect and burns their Bonus Action Points at the start of turn.

Dispels at the end of combat.

The madness of the Blood Moon - so they said in that unfortunate village where a villager who was infected with rabies from a strange wolf - sucked his family and several of his nearest neighbours to the bones. The villager was killed by the county watchmen, but the disease spread to one of the guards and the new patient managed to suck the juices out of his former fellows. The madness of the Blood Moon lasted for decades, until a scholarly wizard came up with the idea of extracting the tainted soul of the last infected into a magical artefact, getting rid of the disease for good. And only a very brave person, thousands of years later, would attempt to curb the power of the Blood Moon.
When attacking a foe with this weapon, you apply Blood Curse to that foe with a [1]% chance for [2] turns.
Casting a spell on a foe, you apply Blood Curse to that foe with a [1]% chance for [2] turn.

This creature takes [1] at the end of its turn. The duration can be stacked.

If creature dies while this curse is active, the one who applied it gets Grace of the Blood Moon for [2] turns.
You regain [1] at the end of each turn.

Once upon a time, there was a master named Gondo. Gondo was famous for his skill with spears. It is said that he could throw a spear to the very top of a long oak tree and pierce its tip with the point. One day a royal herald came to the village, announcing a great tournament where the finest masters of arms would gather to compete for the right to become the crown prince's squire. Long may it be, short may it be, Gondo made his way to this great tournament. But already in town after submitting his bid, he learned that the tournament had been bought by a councillor who planned to promote his son as squire by rigging the rules of the tournament so that the masters would get the worst weapons for them. Gondo realised that he would most likely be screwed by the bow competition - so he decided to resort to trickery himself. He bought an enchantment from a local wizard and crafted a bow that would be very accurate and very powerful. However, Gondo's cunning was discovered by a councillor, who, through intrigue, had the master executed, and the enchanted bow ended up in the royal treasury.
You gain +[1]~[2] to Attack Rolls with this bow.

It is not known who owned this perfect instrument of warfare, but the bow was perfectly suited for the skilled masters. The pleasant handle, the sophisticated and comfortable bowstring, the fine tuning of the tension - everything in this bow was created for true archers. One can only hope that this majestic weapon will fall into the right, good hands.

You deal an extra [1] to humanoids. Attack Rolls with this bow are higher by [2].

Effectiveness increases every [3] levels.

It is no secret that elves are recognised masters of ranged combat. Their weapons are known throughout Faerûn, and their bows are characterised by their fine craftsmanship and meticulous attention to detail. This particular bow was made a long time ago, but it has not worn out since - the bowstring can still cut a goblin's body in half. It contains an ancient enchantment that gives it very good combat performance, and it is obviously the best choice for any connoisseur of elven weaponry.
Rolling a [1] or less on an Attack die, while attacking with this bow - reroll the die.

One of the old bows of the nomadic centaurs, which they used to use for raiding humanoids. A strange power is contained in this bow, accelerating the arrow so that it vibrates terribly in flight, causing tearing wounds to whoever is in the path of that arrow.
Creature that takes damage from this bow must succeed a Constitution Saving Throw([1]) or suffer a rupture.

The drow Lhaenero was a loner, as he loved travelling through the most impassable corners of the Underdark. He often encountered impossible gorges and chasms on his way, and a magic artefact that he always carried with him helped him to overcome them. The crystal, which he had once taken from a long-dead underground creature, was inserted into the handle of his shortbow and allowed him to levitate above the surface for short periods of time, enhancing his leaps and cushioning his fall. Unfortunately, Lhaenero was not very vigilant and was mercilessly slaughtered by drow fanatics in his sleep on a campout.
Fall damage is halved and jump distance is increased by [1].
The exquisite bow, made in the royal armoury, has a very noticeable gleam that speaks of powerful charms applied.

The poachers formed a whole gang, which greatly hindered the king's hunting in the local lands. King Sinnicus I commanded to get rid of the poachers, and the ringleader was to be quartered for the fun of the crowd. The "hunt for hunters" did not last long, as the guards simply drove trained wild boars into the lands and caught a couple of poachers in the act. A few hours of horrific tortures and the bandits gave away the base of their associates. The poachers' possessions, including this magic bow, were given to the Guard for their ingenuity in catching the criminals.
Attacking beasts or fiends with this bow, you deal an extra [1].

The fine silver frame seems to glisten with the bright moonlight, giving hope to all who hold this bow in their hands. A gift of the gods, dug up from ancient times, it was probably meant to stay where it was - but here it is, back in the mortal world, ready to help do great things and change the fate of thousands of people.
Missing creatures with this bow, you gain [1] charge of The Moon's Lightness.

+[1] to a ranged weapon Attack Rolls for each charge of this effect. Doesn't dispels after a Long Rest.

Dispels on hit with a ranged weapon.

Al-Dilārick often travelled on special quests from the king's chancelleries, solving the most complex political issues - often of a nature that required the use of force and cunning. At one point, Al-Dilārick gathered a powerful group around him: the wizard Negleus, the bandit Schun, and a silent knight from the Tranquil Valley. Their party often emerged unscathed from difficult adventures, aided by the wizard's enchantments, including this bow, which let loose arrows with full force even at low tension.

This bow's damage dice cannot roll lower than [1].

All bonus damage dice affecting this bow's damage also cannot roll lower than [1].

In a distant land, long ago, on the highest peak of snow-capped mountains, there lived a monk. And many warriors went to this monk because they knew that he possessed the secret heavenly practices of taming thunder and other heavenly forces. But the monk rejected these warriors, because mortals should not know the secrets of heaven. One of the barbarians of the Olaine clan took offence and with the help of a warlock brought a curse on the monk, which forced him to come down to civilisation for treatment. Here the warlock was waiting for him, having brutally sacrificed the monk and imprisoned his soul in a cursed vessel. A piece of the enlightened monk's soul also went to the offended warrior, who used it to saturate his bow.
Creature that takes damage from this bow must succeed a Strength Saving Throw([1]) or be thrown back for [2].
A mysterious slime coats the handle of the bow, magically applying a powerful poison to all arrows fired from it.

This weapon once belonged to a champion famous in many lands, of nomadic peoples, who as a child was enslaved by one of the kings of antiquity, who made him his gladiator at the arms shows. The nomadic warrior became one of the best at his profession, especially excelling at wielding a bow and arrow. As a reward for one of the competitions, the organisers gave him a special bow of indefatigability, which helped him recover his strength and go into the fight as if nothing had happened.
Dealing damage to a creature with this bow, you have a [1]% chance to regain a Superiority Die.

It is believed that this artefact was originally enchanted by one of the demi-deites as being able to set those struck by an arrow from the bow on fire. But after millennia, the bow seems to have lost its powers, yet it still inflicts terrible damage on targets engulfed in fire.

Attacking with this bow a burning targets, you land a Critical Hit with a [1]% chance.

The effect also triggers on targets affected by Hellfire, Holy Fire or similar effect.

It is no secret that the snowy lands are swarming with all sorts of monsters of unimaginable size, and the northern peoples had to come up with all sorts of inventions to survive in such an unfavourable environment. One such invention was the northern bow, which was believed to be a gift to the Quiet Tundra Clan after numerous sacrifices to the northern idols. This bow was incredibly powerful and could strike particularly large beasts and monsters that even a group of hunters would never have been able to handle.
When dealing damage with ranged weapon attack to creatures that have [3] HP or more, you deal [1].

The grove was never peaceful. Many wanted to challenge the balance of nature, but the druids successfully repelled all attacks. Once, the tide of enemies grew so high that the High Druid begged Silvanus for great gifts that would help them maintain the balance. And Silvanus had mercy on his servants, showering the grove with majestic weapons that could withstand the onslaught of invaders. However, 200 years later, the grove was invaded and plundered anyway - by intrigue from within.
Creature taking damage from this bow must succeed a Dexterity Saving Throw([1]) or be entangled.

The elegant Shortbow, lined with gold alloys, was the "diamond in the crown" of the royal armoury of one of the oldest kingdoms. Its magical properties were legendary - in fact, according to stories, it could heal even the most severe wounds by transferring the life force from those who would be struck with it. Over the millennia, it has passed through many hands, but it became most famous in the hands of Captain Ankhem Zhalimkhaner of the Guard, whose name it was named after.
Dealing damage to a foes with this bow, you regain [1]% HP.

A masterfully crafted bow of unknown origin, enchanted to serve its owner by endowing them with a feat of unprecedented dexterity. It has been through many wars and has almost always been the reason for saving the lives of its owners.

Two brothers found a magical maiden on a mountain peak. Craig drank her blood to end hunger and killed her to gain youth. After bragging to his brother, Zilek strangled Craig with a string made from the maiden's hair, later using it as a bowstring until his peaceful death decades later.
Dealing damage to a wet creature with this bow, you create a [1] electrified puddle beneath it for [2] turns.

An extremely powerful bow capable of inflicting terrible damage. The last time it had been used by an underground gnome who hunted the mightiest duergars, and did so with great success. No one could resist the power of this weapon, and even the strongest ancient magic could not create a barrier through which an arrow from this bow could not pass. But who possessed it before and who created it - is a huge mystery.
Killing a foes with this bow, you gain [1] charge of Dreaded Shot. When scoring a Critical Hit with a ranged weapon, you lose [1] charge of Dreaded Shot.
When landing a Critical Hit with a ranged weapon, you lose [1] charge of Dreaded Shot.
Landing a Critical Hit with a ranged weapon makes it three times more powerful than a normal one.

Few could boast of their athletic qualities when it comes to dodging ten arrows at once from the most accurate archers. However, only the owner of this bow could do so, for it is the bow that gives such extraordinary powers.

From the ancient gnomish language, "Jijig" translates to "Small". This bow, according to legend, was made by gnomish craftsmen and used a combination of perfect mechanisms and extremely rare magic. Each shot from this bow inevitably shrinks the victim, equalling the size of the average gnome. Many gnome kings have since used the Jijig in duels with other races, and have often emerged victorious even in battles against orcs.
Dealing damage to a creatures with this bow, you have a [1]% chance to inflict Shrinkage I on them for [2] turns. Repeated attacks inflict Shrinkage II for [3] turns and Shrinkage III for [4] turn.
+[1] to AC. This creature's weight and size class are reduced by [3].

+[1] to AC. This creature's weight and size class are reduced by [3].

After this effect ends, Shrinkage I is inflicted for [4] turns.

+[1] to AC. This creature's weight and size class are reduced by [3].

After this effect ends, Shrinkage II is inflicted for [4] turn.
A good enchanted shield that has served more than one master, and judging by its appearance, has seen a lot of fights.
The skilfully crafted shield evokes the appearance of an impressive artefact of ancient times. It was usually used to equip healers at the rear of an army.
This shield is stinking of sea spirit, seaweed, and seems quite fragile, but inexplicably arouses awe in those who look at it, awakening fear of the bottomless abysses of the sea.

Belonging to one of the greatest ork warriors, it was not the only shield in his collection, but one of those enchanted by elven slaves. Such a shield could certainly enhance any warrior, making him even more fierce in battle.
Forged in one of the underground cities of the Shanatar Empire, this artifact is extremely good for underground quick skirmishes, but will not lose its effectiveness in protracted battles.
An unremarkable shield, almost child-sized in appearance, yet possessing powerful magic. It was probably lost a long time ago by one of the students of the mages' guild during the field exams.
The magical properties of this shield allow to slightly slow down the projectiles and strikes from foes. A very useful piece of equipment, made by dwarven craftsmen in ancient times.
You take [1] less damage from all weapon or unarmed attacks.

This buckler would probably never have survived this long had its owner, Neronian, not been fatally stabbed with a shadow poison and then miraculously saved by a cult of halflings ruled by a powerful wizard, who in turn asked the hero to get rid of a particularly dangerous fey in the mines - for which he enchanted the outfit for the scourge hunter.
Undead, monstrosities, fiends and fey deal [1] less damage to you.

This shield, crafted from weathered oak, is surprisingly lightweight yet embodies remarkable resilience. It is said to fortify the human spirit. As the battle intensifies, the oak's heartwood resonates with a faint, steady echo, invigorating the weary body.
When you have less than [1]% HP, you gain +[2] Constitution(up to [3]).

The dulled and venerable shield of worn war steel bears upon it gilded engravings of a forgotten order. Rumours circulate that the artifact possesses an intriguing property: whenever a sacred incantation emanates from its bearer, the shield becomes suffused with a faint warmth, as if the metal itself remembers ancient blessings and kindles within itself a spark of restorative power.
By healing with a paladin's spell in combat, regain Lay on Hands Charge.

Upon this weathered shield, hewn from scraps of timber, crudely depicted is a strange white hand. Despite its modest form, the white gleam of enchantment clearly whispers of arcane magic. When fate deals its cruelest blow, the symbol upon the shield bends the unseen threads of destiny, offering the bearer a solitary, desperate chance to snatch victory from the jaws of defeat.
If a [1] is rolled on the Saving Throw die, you reroll it.

The artifact, crafted from gnarled branches and imbued with the whispers of forgotten groves, appears less like a shield and more like a fragment of the forest itself. Wild vines, etched upon its surface, writhe with unnatural energy. It seems that the shield resonates with primal earth magic: when raised for protection, the vines seem to obey a primal command, tearing themselves from the earth to entwine and hinder those who dare to approach the shield.
At the start of combat, entangling vines for [2] turns rise from the ground at [1] around you.

The concoction of roughly hewn planks, studded with a nightmarish multitude of blackened iron spikes, harbours a grim history. The shield was crafted by a dreadful raider of cities, with each spike forged from the pinnacle of a town hall. Now saturated with echoes of countless killings, the shield once more thirsts for blood.
Those attacking you in melee must succeed a Constitution <LSTag Tooltip="SavingThrow">Saving Throw</LSTag> or receive <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="BLEEDING">Bleeding</LSTag>.

Fashioned from tarnished metal, the round shield bears the scars of countless battles, each notch and dent a mark of its rich and enduring history. Legends speak of a noble cleric who, in the face of insurmountable adversity, stood resolute, shielding his companions from harm with this very artifact. Every blemish serves as a testament to the shield's activation, a life preserved through its divine intervention.
When taking critical hit, you apply Barrier of Faith to yourself and allies in [3] for [2] turns.

+[1]~[2] to Saving Throws.

Dispels when wielder of Halo of Salvation gets hit.

This deceptively simple oak shield bears the unmistakable scars of innumerable battles. These nicks and gouges are not mere signs of wear but rather testaments to the resilience of the shield, each one containing a fragment of the unwavering spirit of the guardian who once wielded this artifact.
When taking damage in combat from a foe, you gain Unwavering Fortitude for [1] turns.

The somber-looking shield, encased in supple dark leather adorned with rivets, forms the visage of a griffin - a symbol of unwavering protection. Garrett fought with such ferocity that even death itself hesitated to claim him. Blows that would fell lesser men merely reverberated under the weight of the bearer's iron defense. Now, whoever wields it shall inherit a fraction of that legendary resolve.

The polished metal shield, smooth from countless prayers, bears at its centre the symbol of a radiant sun. This relic of a forgotten temple was once carried by a forgotten priestess, renowned for her unwavering devotion. Her piety was so profound, her faith such a beacon, that she somehow imbued some ritual shield with a fragment of her inner divine strength. When the temple was plundered, subsequent bearers felt a settling resolve descend upon them, shielding their minds from doubt.

The blackened metal of this towering shield was forged deep within a mountain, infused with the stoic spirit of dwarves. Thick and resilient, the metal seems to bear the full weight of attacks, leaving the bearer surprisingly unscathed. This shield sings a song of pragmatism, affirming the dwarves' belief that a well-crafted shield is all the magic a warrior needs.
You take [1] less damage from all weapon or unarmed attacks.

This peculiar relic is a legend among sailors. It once belonged to a legendary captain who, after suffering a shipwreck and losing his entire crew, was nearly drowned but was saved by a sea spirit that placed him on a shell and carried him through the waves to the nearest shore. Afterwards, the captain discovered that the shell was magical and imbued its bearer with oceanic magic. The stronger the warrior, the more powerful the surge of oceanic wonder will be.
Half your fighter's and barbarian's levels is added to the damage of your cantrips.

Fashioned from slender oak and banded with steel, this artifact was last wielded by the captain of the Bloodhounds, Katrena Slyblade. She was renowned for her daring raids and personal combat prowess. Undoubtedly, her magical shield, enchanted over 13,000 years ago, aided her in the latter. When a blow is parried with perfect precision, the shield vibrates in response, empowering the warrior's next decisive strike. Katrena perished 280 years ago in one of her drunken brawls, and this artifact was lost for centuries thereafter.
Dodging an attack in combat, regain a Superiority Die and War Priest Point with a [1]% chance.

Covered in grime, the silver alloy, with patches of cracked paint depicting the sun and rainbow, clearly bears witness to better days. Legends speak of the Shield of the Great Knight, crafted for the grand expedition into the realm of the dead. This artifact, ablaze with righteous magical light that scorches unholy flesh, was lost to the ages, along with all men hopes pinned upon it.

The sturdy oak shield possesses a peculiar magic, clearly at odds with its utilitarian appearance. Centuries ago, it was wielded by a warrior of unparalleled beauty and oratorical talents, inspiring allies not only with martial prowess but also with a thunderous voice that instilled courage in even the weakest hearts. Through countless battles, the very wood of the shield became infused with a fragment of this paladin's inspiring aura.

Dodging an attack in combat regains you [1].

Effectiveness increases from Charisma Modifier(rounded down).

When devout believer Kolento suffered a grievous neck injury and was on the verge of death, the shield suddenly blazed with holy radiance, imbuing the wound with healing energy. But miracles always come at a cost. The light flickered with echoes of Kolento's mortal wounds, draining his strength. Had his resolve and faith not been steadfast, the light would have sapped his strength as much as it bestowed it. Lost for many generations, Kolento's artifact serves as a potent reminder of the price of unwavering faith.
Taking damage from a foe in combat, you gain Test of Faith for [2] turns.
Regain [1] at the end of your turn, but succeed a Wisdom Saving Throw([2]) to not catch Sickness for [3] turns.

The charred, broken shield flickers with a faint purple glow. Legend speaks of the Star of Many Shadows, which was captured by elves and shattered into several pieces, gifted to heroes of that era. One of the shards was bestowed upon the legendary halfling Shileyla, who embedded it into his shield. Interestingly, the shield retained its properties even after the battle with the dragon. But not Shileyla.

The one attacking you in combat must succeed a Constitution Saving Throw or become silenced for [1] turns.

Effectiveness of DC is increases from your Spell Save DC.

Captain Valigar Cortalis led a convoy carrying provisions to the besieged city. During a treacherous ambush by gnolls, nearly the entire unit was slaughtered, and defeat seemed inevitable, when suddenly the captain's shield erupted in crimson flames, incinerating the gnoll chieftain and turning the tide of battle — such was the tale, and since then Valigar Cortalis came to be known as "The Dragon."
Taking melee damage during combat, you ignite the attacker. You're ignoring targets' Immunity to[1].

"They say courage cannot be forged. But take hold of an adamantium bulwark and feel the spirit of a thousand battles rise within you. No blow shall find a breach, no foe shall claim victory. This shield is not just of metal, but of the craftsmanship honed over millennia of dwarven smithing." - Belgar Stonehammer, blacksmith.

This magnificent golden shield gleams with an otherworldly radiance, adorned with a single colossal ruby, pulsating with celestial energy. When evil raises its weapon against the bearer of the shield of justice, the ruby erupts in a blinding light, leaving the creature stunned and disoriented, its malevolent intent thwarted by the righteous power emanating from the shield.
When undead, monstrosities, fiends or fey attack you, they must succeed a Constitution Saving Throw([1]) or be stunned for [2] turns.

This colossal shield, forged from black steel, stands as a chilling testament to the might of the Absolute. Formerly belonging to one of the powerful adherents of the cult, who nonetheless met his wicked demise at the hands of his own comrades, the artifact was then pilfered by goblins. Will you harness the magical properties of the Aegis to combat the influence of the Absolute, or will its touch claim you as well?
When taking damage from a foe in combat, you gain Supreme Absolute Protection for [2] turns with a [1]% chance.

Crafted with elven finesse, this shield was not intended for its current purpose. Millennia ago, it symbolized hope, the bright spirit, and fervent flame. But time passed, and other forces, sinister forces, laid their hands on the legendary artifact. They defiled the relic and turned it into an instrument of vengeance, carrying within it a vengeful light that annihilates all living things.
When taking damage from a foe in combat, you gain [1] charge of Vengeful Light.

Vengeance is near, and the shield is increasingly infused with a fury of light.

Dispels at the end of combat.
After accumulating [1] charges of Vengeful Light, you absorb them and unleash a vengeful Blast of Light.
Deals [1] to all creatures within a [2] radius.

Forged from ancient metal in the darkest corners of Faerûn, this shield gleams with an ominous, cold fire. Swirls of tarnished gold adorn its surface, whispering of forgotten rituals and sorcerous pacts. Legends proclaim that the Nightshield was created by a desperate civilization, faced with oblivion. Teetering on the brink of catastrophe, they struck a desperate bargain with an entity dwelling in the black depths of the cosmos - the Black Star. It was the slumbering deity of night and oblivion, offering them the great artifact in exchange for the growing darkness in their souls. But will it grant you victory in the face of impending defeat, or will the Black Star claim you entirely when the time comes to settle the debt?
When taking damage from a foe in combat, you gain [1] charge of Dark Bond.

Darkness increasingly consumes your soul, the Black Star takes its toll.

Dispels at the end of combat.
After accumulating [1] charges of Dark Bond, you absorb them and gain Gift of the Black Star for [2] turns.

+[1] to all Abilities.
Damage dealt to you is cancelled.
No effect can be applied to you.

Dispels when killing a foe.

Engulfed by the sea depths during a storm, this handaxe became the final refuge for the soul of a sailor whose life was cut short in search of unknown shores. Saturated with salt and wind, each strike of this weapon fills the air with the scent of distant seas, enveloping a foe in coolness and moisture, as if a wave leaves a trail on the sand. The spirit of the mariner, seeking peace, found eternity in his handaxe, gifting its bearer a piece of his endless voyage across seas hidden in the mist of time.
Dealing any damage while standing on a water surface, you make the target wet for [1] turns.

In an era of forgotten wars, a warrior named Adrian betrayed his comrades, tempted by enemy promises. As punishment, his spirit was sealed within the handaxe he wielded. This artifact, absorbing his fervent glow of faith and subsequent curse, became a source of noble magical light. Adrian, now a prisoner of his own weapon, constantly reminds of the price of betrayal, sharing his pain in every ray of the sun.

Attacking illuminated enemies with this handaxe, you deal [1], but also [2] to yourself.
Triggers even on a miss.

When the lands of Faerûn were engulfed by a grim plague, the great healer Mirren created this relic in an attempt to tame the disease. However, the weapon was secretly cursed by demonic foes, turning it into an instrument of ailment. Mirren, exhausted by the failure of her intent, hid the handaxe in hopes that the dangerous curse would be forgotten forever.
Taking damage from this handaxe, target recieves [1] charge of Prolonged Wound.

Creature loses [1] of its Movement Speed and [2] to Attack Rolls for each charge of this effect.

Removed by healing or combat ending.

Forged in the heart of the Icewind Dale mountains, this handaxe is a creation of ancient ice troll shamans. Legends say the blade was tempered in the waters of a deep submountain lake, known for its magical properties.

Taking damage from this handaxe, target must succeed a Constitution Saving Throw or receive Ice Grip until the end of its next turn.

Saving Throw DC depends on your Spell Save DC.

Creature cannot move and take Bonus Actions.

Removed when starting to burn.

Crafted from rare metal, repeatedly illuminated by the first rays of the sun, this axe shimmers with shades of dawn and is quite light. The secret of its making is lost to the ages, but it is said to have been created by great blacksmiths who sought to capture the moment of night turning into day.

Forged in the centuries when the undead began to rise from the earth's depths, this handaxe was blessed by the mightiest of people living at that time. It emits a warm light, empowering its wielder in the fight against the forces of darkness. The artifact, adorned with runes of ancient vows, symbolizes the eternal struggle between life and those who rejected its laws.
You also deal [1] with this handaxe against the undead.

Forged in the depths of forgotten dungeons, where light does not penetrate, this artifact absorbs the essence of darkness and invisibility. It is believed that the first owner of this handaxe was an assassin who dedicated his life to the art of unseen movement and lethal strikes. The power of the primitive seal on the axe, surprisingly, has retained its strength to this day.

Attacking with this handaxe from stealth, you force target to succeed a Constitution Saving Throw or suffer from enhanced Bleeding. Effect triggers even on a miss.

Difficulty Class depends on your Manoeuvre DC.

The handle of the axe is made from magical wood, cut down in the Unknown Forest. Due to the abundance of mockingbirds there, the wood is colloquially known as "mockingbird". With each swing, a clear echo rings out, drawing attention and confusing a foe, making them more vulnerable to attacks.
Dealing damage with this handaxe, you apply Mocker's Mark on a target until the start of its turn.
<LSTag Tooltip="AttackRoll">Attack Rolls</LSTag> against this creature have an <LSTag Tooltip="Advantage">Advantage</LSTag>.

Woven of iron from the depths of an ancient forest where wild vines wrap around every tree and stone, this axe was imbued with the juice of the most powerful and stubborn plants. The artifact was created by a forest spirit, aiming to protect its domain from invaders, and gifted to one of the forest elves who roamed these lands.
When attacking a target standing in wild vines with this handaxe, you apply Entanglement to that target.

This axe is saturated with runes, applied under the cover of night by a greedy witch long ago. With each strike of this axe, invisible shadowy tendrils weave around the victim, as if the night itself becomes an ally of the wielder of this relic.

Dealing damage with this handaxe, you apply Shadow Vines on a target for [1] turns.

Triggers no more than once per turn.

Saving Throws -[1]
Melee Spell Attack Rolls against this creature have an Advantage.

The blade, constantly shimmering with the soft light of coals, ignites upon impact, enveloping the target in a fiery halo. The warrior Galthar, the first owner of the axe, used it to liberate his people, turning battles into dances of fire and ash. This axe is not only a weapon of destruction but also a symbol of the will to victory, capable of awakening the fervor of battle and resilience in the hearts of warriors.
Deal a scorching strike to the target, inflicting an extra [2] and possibly igniting it.

Centuries ago, a clumsy wizard named Filbert made a pact with time, seeking eternal youth. However, instead of the desired immortal youth, time deceived him and cursed everything he wore, including this axe, making old everything it touches. Filbert never learned to control his time-cursed artifacts and died quite early, becoming a legendary subject of mockery among his descendants.

Taking any damage from you, target must succeed a Constitution Saving Throw or receive [1] charge of Curse of Aging. You have a [2]% chance to also receive [1] charge of this curse.

Difficulty Class depends on your Spell Save DC.

-[1] to AC for each charge of this curse.
Curse does not dispels over time.

If charges reach [2] or more, curse dispels, and the creature takes [3].

As you study this ancient double-headed axe, its weathered surface tells a tale of countless battles. The perfectly balanced twin blades, forged from an unusually resilient metal, seem to resonate with your own physical power. According to the dusty chronicles of the Sword Coast's warrior-smiths, such weapons were once crafted for the champions of Tempus, blessed to enhance the natural might of those deemed worthy to wield them. The axe's simple yet profound enchantment suggests it was created during the Age of Humanity, when magic was often woven with elegance rather than extravagance.

As you examine this unusual trident, its metal grows uncomfortably hot to the touch, yet you find yourself unable to let go. Consulting ancient maritime texts, you discover scattered references to a mysterious cult of deep-sea fire worshippers - their sacred texts speak of weapons forged in underwater volcanoes. While much of the trident's history remains shrouded in mystery, one peculiar detail catches your eye - the three prongs are marked with archaic symbols representing pain, flame, and transcendence. Perhaps the weapon's true power reveals itself only to those willing to embrace its burning touch?
Grants +[1] Strength and Constitution while Burning.

Upon closer inspection, ethereal whispers seem to dance around this staff's twisted crown - a mesmerizing display that brings to mind the northern lights. While studying its peculiar properties, you discover its paradoxical nature in an ancient druidic manuscript: it was crafted by a circle of druids who believed in maintaining nature's balance through both communion and culling. The flowing patterns of light, according to the text, are the spirits of creatures judged by previous wielders, though whether they remain as witnesses or guides is unclear. As you hold it, you feel an uncanny ability to both commune with beasts and discern their darkest corruptions.
Deal additional damage equal to your Wisdom Modifier against Beasts and Monstrosities.

In your hands, the twin blades of this ancient battleaxe radiate an unsettling warmth. As you delve into its mysteries, you witness a peculiar phenomenon - when striking burning flesh, the axe's metal seems to drink in the flames like a thirsty wanderer. A fragment of scorched parchment you discovered suggests this weapon was forged by a renegade priest of Kossuth, who believed that true mastery of fire meant not just wielding it, but consuming its essence. The axe's hunger for flame persists to this day, though whether its creator achieved their burning ambition remains unknown.
When you deal damage to a Burning foe with this axe, you absorb the flames and regain [1].

What you initially took for a simple greatclub reveals an unusual affinity for lightning that becomes apparent when you examine it in a storm. Your research in the archives of a long-abandoned mage tower suggests this weapon was part of a larger experiment in harnessing natural electricity. The creator's notes, though mostly destroyed by water damage, hint at an attempt to create weapons for an elite guard stationed in the Stormhorns. You notice intricate runes etched along its haft, designed to channel and amplify electrical energies from the ground up - though their full potential seems to awaken only when standing where lightning has struck.
While standing on electrified surface, this weapon deals [1].

This pike bears a bizarre history that you piece together from fragments of a shepherd's diary found in the Sword Coast's agricultural archives. This broken weapon, it seems, belonged to a renowned herder who was repeatedly polymorphed into a sheep by a mischievous archmage. Rather than break under the humiliation, the shepherd somehow turned these transformations into a source of vengeful power. The pike's blade carries faint etchings of sheep's wool patterns, though whether these were added as decoration or mockery remains unclear. The peak itself shimmers with bright peach flashes and is already more of an etheric artifact than an ordinary trinket of the Material Plane.
When transformed into a <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="POLYMORPH_SHEEP">Sheep</LSTag>, you gain <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="MAG_WEAPON110_T_VFX">Shepherd's Vengeance</LSTag>.
Your next successful melee weapon attack is guaranteed to be a Critical Hit, and the Critical Hit damage is tripled ([1] additional damage dice).

Amidst the pages of a condemned executioner's journal, you discover unsettling references to this double-headed axe. The writer describes how the weapon began "collecting" the souls of those it slew, growing more demanding with each execution. The more you study its cruel edges, the more you sense the trapped spirits within - their whispers promise power, but at a terrible price. In your research, you uncover that the axe was forged in a forgotten ritual involving a possessed headsman's blade and the remnants of a necromancer's staff. The marriage of these dark artifacts created something hungry, something that feeds not just on death, but on the very essence of its victims.
When you kill a foe with the Soul Reaver, gain [1]~[2] Defiled Soul Fragments.

The scores of all your Abilities become equal to at least [6].
Souls within the axe torment you and with [5]% chance can inflict [2] on you.
Upon gathering [3] fragments, you absorb them and gain Reaver's Judgment for [4] turns.

This effect does not dispels over time or after Long Rests, but dispels if you unequip the Soul Reaver.
All your successful melee weapon attacks are Critical Hits.
While your HP are below [1]%, you gain immunity to[2].

Upon grasping this pristine spear, a bone-deep chill creeps through your fingers. Within the archives of the Icespire Peak monastery, you find mentions of an ancient tribunal that passed judgment using weapons imbued with winter's essence. The spear's unusually sharp tip, you notice, never seems to gather frost despite its perpetual coldness. A partially preserved scroll suggests this was the favored weapon of the tribunal's executioner, who believed that true justice, like the harshest winter, should strike twice - first with the blade, then with the cold. The rest of the scroll has been damaged by time, leaving the fate of both executioner and tribunal shrouded in mystery.
Creature that takes a Critical Hit from you must recieve Mark of Frost for [2] turns.
Creature takes [1] when damaged by any means.

Studying this otherworldly halberd, you're struck by how its blade seems to shimmer like starlight. Through consultation with a weathered planar grimoire, you discover references to weapons forged in the vast emptiness of the Astral Sea, where isolation spans eternities. The weapon's distinctive head bears geometric patterns that match no earthly design - instead resembling the abstract forms that float in the silver void between realities. Most intriguing is a note describing how these artifacts were used by the githyanki's solitary scouts, who drew power from the absolute solitude of astral space. The weapon's purpose in reaching the Material Plane remains unknown, though its affinity for isolation persists.
While no allies are within [1] of you, this halberd deals [2], and Constitution is increased by [3] (up to [4]).
There are no allies nearby and the Astral Wanderer has strengthened with magic.

Running your fingers along this unassuming staff, you discover its peculiar ability to drink in shadows. A dusty journal from Candlekeep's restricted section tells of Sister Moira, a cleric of Mask who grew disillusioned with traditional temple worship. She crafted this staff in the sewers beneath Baldur's Gate, infusing it with shadow essence during the longest night of the year. According to the journal, Moira used it to infiltrate and spy upon other temples, believing that divine wisdom lay in understanding the secrets of both the holy and the profane. The last entry mentions her departure to the Cloakwood - though whether she found her answers in those dark woods, none can say.
While you are sneaking, your Wisdom is increased by [1].

Within a sealed dwarven vault, you discovered this remarkable warhammer alongside fragmentary notes from the legendary artificer Drugan Spellforge. The hammer, you learn, was his attempt to solve the ancient problem of depleted spell reserves during long expeditions. The crystalline head appears to be a modified spell battery, its runes precisely calibrated to convert the energy of a deadly strike into pure magical potential. According to Drugan's last notes, he never fully stabilized the conversion process - the hammer would occasionally overload, causing "interesting" magical accidents, tearing the fabric of the Weave. One is left to wonder what kind of tearing this dwarf had in mind?

Killing a hostile humanoid with this warhammer restores [1] Level [2] Spell Slot.

Triggers no more than once per turn.

This radiant greatsword bears the hallmarks of the Silver Crusade, an ancient brotherhood of paladins who stood guard at the boundaries between the Material Plane and the Far Realm. Your research in the depths of Candlekeep unveils accounts of their centuries-long vigil against mind flayer incursions. The sword's distinctive cruciform design, you discover, was specifically crafted to channel divine light through the wielder's own mental fortitude - a direct counter to the illithids' psychic assaults. While the Order itself was thought lost during the Great Purge of the elder brain Xax'tal'han, their weapons were said to be scattered across Faerûn, waiting for new champions to take up their ancient cause.
Aberrations that attack you, take [1] in return and may be blinded.

The glaive's presence fills you with an inexplicable dread, as if you're being watched by something ancient and unfathomable. In your dreams, you glimpse fragments of its purpose - a being of absolute darkness, using this weapon as its anchor to influence the mortal realm. The few texts that dare mention it speak only in terrified whispers of the Dark One, a deity so obscure that even its name has been lost to time. You've noticed that the weapon seems to act of its own accord at times, choosing its victims with an intelligence that no mere enchanted blade should possess. Perhaps most disturbing is the realization that you're not truly its wielder, but merely its temporary vessel.

At the start of each of your turns in combat, ALL creatures within [1] must succeed on a Constitution Saving Throw ([2]) or be instantly slain by the Dark One's inexorable will.

Should the wielder fall, their entire party shares their fate.
You fool! You must realize you are doomed. The Harvester of the Dark One brooks no survivors...

In ancient manuscripts of Necropolis, you discover a tale of a proud elven archer who served at the court of Evereska. When plague claimed his family, he set forth to seek Death itself, challenging it to a duel. The Lady of Doom, amused by his audacity, accepted the challenge with a condition: should he lose, he would forge a bow from his own bones, eternally bound to her service. Now this dreadful trophy rests in your hands - unnaturally cold, its runes pulsing with sickly green light. They say arrows loosed from it can find their way to the very soul of their mark, leaving wounds that neither magic nor time can mend. Even liches and ancient vampires fear this weapon, for it carries within it a fragment of Death's own power.

You marvel at how this ethereal club barely exists in the material plane, its form ever-shifting like a tempest bound in chains. Among treatises of the Ethereal Plane's mysteries, you discover tales of weapons forged from captured storms. A master of the Ethereal arts, it is said, once imprisoned a raging tempest within a simple club, believing that pure elemental fury would prove mightier than mere wood and steel. The weapon's misty surface ripples with captured gales, and in moments of perfect stillness, you swear you can hear the storm howling within its ethereal prison.
When hit by this greatclub, the creature must succeed a Strength Saving Throw([1]) or be knocked back [2].

Deep within an ancient mountain library, you discover scrolls speaking of the Storm Speakers - a legendary clan of warrior-shamans from the Spine of the World. Their chronicles tell of hammers forged in the heart of tempests, where the high shaman would channel heaven's lightning into molten metal while apprentices sang ancient songs of thunder, amplifying the enchantment. As you study the intricate patterns etched upon the haft, you realize you hold one such hammer in your hands. The last records of the Storm Speakers date to the Time of Troubles - they say the clan vanished when gods walked Faerûn. Yet even centuries later, this hammer still resonates with the echoes of their ancient thunder rituals.
On hit, force all creatures within [1] to succeed a Constitution Saving Throw([2]) or take [3].

Within the blade's perfect symmetry lies a tale of unmatched craftsmanship. As your fingers trace the ancient dwarven runes upon the pommel, they reveal the mark of 'Karathos' - a name whispered with reverence in the halls of Waterdeep's Weaponsmiths. Among yellowed scrolls and faded manuscripts, you discover chronicles of this master whose understanding of steel transcended mere smithing. Through arcane geometry and principles long lost, he imbued his blades with an almost sentient balance. The sword's peculiar crossguard, you notice, seems to guide your hand after each swing, as if the blade itself yearns to find its mark. Such mastery of non-magical craft speaks to why the secrets of Karathos remain sought after to this day, though none have matched his artistry since his passing into legend.
On miss, gain <LSTag Type="Status" Tooltip="WEAPON121">Balanced Strike</LSTag>.
Your next melee weapon attack is guaranteed to be a Critical Hit.

In the hallowed depths of Candlekeep's forbidden vaults lies a tale most grievous, penned in trembling hands. For here, amidst ancient scrolls and forgotten tomes, rests the chronicle of Archwarden Lysander, whose holy crusade twisted from righteousness into darkest heresy. When his brethren sought to cast him from grace, the divine ritual wrought something terrible indeed - a fusion of sacred judgment and mortal folly, bound forever in steel and spirit. Now this ancient maul weeps radiance from its wounds, each mark of corruption blazing with heaven's own light, as if the very stars themselves weep for its wielder's fate. Some whisper that Lysander yet walks the realms, caught betwixt salvation and damnation, seeking redemption through the very instrument of his fall.

You now have [1] reaction points. When a foe attacks you in melee, automatically spend a reaction to perform a weapon attack.

The Wrath of Retribution does not allow you to manually control counterattacks with this weapon.

Within the pages of a time-worn journal, you discover the tale of General Dustin the Just, whose noble crusade into the Shadowfell's depths led to his doom. As you hold this fell pike, its edges perpetually shrouded in writhing darkness, you sense how its master's obsession with conquering the shadow realm drew the attention of an ancient shadow dragon. The dragon's "gift" proved a most cruel curse, transforming both weapon and wielder into creatures of twilight. Now the pike hungers eternally, much as its former master is said to hunt still, forever caught between light and shadow, neither flesh nor shade. In your grasp, it thirsts for life itself, each strike threatening to drain the very essence from those it pierces.
When attacking a foe with this pike while in shadows, regain [1] and force the target to succeed a Constitution Saving Throw([2]) or suffer Bleeding for [3] turns.

Amidst ancient tomes of the Astral Watchers lies the tale of this remarkable crossbow, one of three mythical instruments wrought by the githyanki arch-artificer K'rax. During the time of the Astral Confluence, when the silver void danced with unprecedented power, K'rax discovered the means to capture the very essence of collapsing astral pools, binding their otherworldly might into weapons of singular purpose. As you hold it, you observe how its crystalline components bend light like ripples in a still pond, and in the deepest darkness, tiny motes of silvered light dance about its limbs like stars in a miniature firmament. The whereabouts of its creator and its sister weapons remain shrouded in mystery, whispered only in legends of the Great Astral Void.
Fire a special bolt that pulls all creatures and objects within [2] towards the impact point unless they succeed a Strength Saving Throw([1]).

In the twilight age of Netheril, when magic flowed like water through the realm, an emperor commanded his finest artificers to forge seven remarkable battleaxes. These weapons were wrought beneath ancient stars, each blade capturing heaven's light within its crystalline patterns, shimmering like the crown of creation itself. Not tools of bloodshed, but instruments of transformation - for the emperor sought to win kingdoms through wisdom rather than war. The weapon's edge glimmers with enchantments most sublime, capable of turning the fiercest foe into the most steadfast ally. Of these seven legendary axes, but three survived the empire's fall, each writing its own tale of bloodless victories that shaped the very face of history.

On attack, force target to succeed a Wisdom Saving Throw([1]) or become your ally for [2] turns.

Triggers no more than once per turn.

Among the darkest volumes of Candlekeep's forbidden archives rests a chronicle of Lady Ravenna, whose noble blood bore a curse as ancient as her lineage. Yet where others sought to break their chains, she yearned to forge them anew. In the sacred forges of Lantan, beneath the watchful eyes of master artificers, she bound her cursed essence to steel and shadow. The hammer's face bears curse-marks wrought in reverse, each line a testament to her mastery over malevolent forces. Though the lady's fate lies lost to time, her creation endures - a beacon to those who would transform their darkness into divine purpose.
While under a curse(excluding Hex!), damaging creatures with this warhammer restores you all Movement Points and deals [1] to the target.
When the wearer has [2]% HP or less and is damaged, they deal [1] to the attacker.
